results.title: Clothes around the world
results.brief_description: Illustrates the variation from country to country in the style of clothes worn and how it is influenced by climate, available materials and the individueal preferences of the people who wear them.

results.title: Cloth: fiber to fabric
results.creator_credit: William Kay and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Cotton, wool and silk are natural fibres, although grown in different ways; synthetic fibres such as rayon and nylon are created by chemical processes. However, all can be woven into cloth on power looms or knitting machines, and the fabric produced can be used for flameproof firemens’ suits, seat belts and parachutes as well as common articles like clothing, rugs, towels.

results.title: Closed Mondays
results.brief_description: In a combination of graphics and three-dimensional clay figures, a little man discovers the world of art. He sees an open door and wanders through into an art exhibition. Paintings come alive and move around him as he watches. As he turns to go, he himself is put on a pedestal and bronzed. A 1975 Academy Award winner. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Close your eyes and hold your stomach
results.brief_description: In a survey of some of the ways Australian children are discovering their own kind of theatre, this film focuses on a touring children’s theatre company, the Pageant Theatre in Education, which tours Australian schools. School children are invited by the actors to participate in the production of each play and their responses influence the shape of the play. Children of different age groups are observed creating fantasy worlds on the one hand and recreating political and social issues on the other. Made with the assistance of the Australian Film & Television School. Narrated by Robert Bruning.

results.title: Close encounters of the sexual kind (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Sequel to “Contraception: ready or not” addressing myths, facts and attitudes towards sexually transmitted diseases. Designed to encourage a responsible attitude towards sex and contraception and the prevention of STD’s. The issues raised include AIDS, the need for medical check-ups, communication and condoms.

results.title: Close-up on Kuwait
results.creator_credit: Rodney Giesler, Derek Armstrong and Kuwait Oil Company Film Unit
results.brief_description: From Kuwait more oil is shipped annually than from any other oil port in the world, bringing in return a wealth of manufactured goods from other countries. A Government Development Board ensures that the country as a whole shares this new prosperity in the free State medical service, schools, and research into cultivation of desert areas.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rodney Giesler, Derek Armstrong and Kuwait Oil Company Film Unit

results.title: Clive eats alligators
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, David Ferris and Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cover to cover”.
Trevor Lunn interviews children’s writer Alison Lester about her children’s books particularly “Clive eats alligators”. She dicusses with children from South Melbourne Primary School her reasons and inspirations for writing and the choice of illustrations in her childrens’ books.

results.title: Climbing plants
results.brief_description: A study of climbing plants, including such “scramblers” as the bramble and the rose; the leaf-holding clematis, the canary creeper, the root climbing ivy, etc.

results.title: Climbing plants
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Botany”.
The film provides a clear explanation of every plant’s need for light and then shows the adaptations which are developed by climbing plants to fulfil this need. Time-lapse techniques are used to illustrate the twining of stems and the growth of different kinds of tendrils. Designed for class-room use.
